elements.title: Human-First Visual Treatment for Agent-Recruited Hosts
elements.problem: Agent-recruited hosts like Dimitri arrive at the platform expecting a continuation of a human conversation, not a corporate SaaS interface. If the first visual impression is a generic marketplace with stock photos and marketing copy, it triggers the same 'third party' distrust that Dimitri expressed on the call. The visual design must feel personal and specific, not institutional and generic.
elements.solution: Use human-scale visual elements: agent photos, guest avatars, property thumbnails. Minimize abstract branding elements (logos, hero sections, feature grids) in favor of concrete, person-specific content. The visual hierarchy should prioritize faces > places > actions > text. Typography should feel like a well-designed email from Bryant, not a marketplace landing page.

evidence.quote: I usually don't deal with third parties.
evidence.insight: The visual design must NOT look like a third party. It must look like Bryant's personal tool for managing Dimitri's sublease.

evidence.quote: LinkedIn sent personal emails... the product felt like an extension of your professional network, not a new website.
evidence.insight: Invite-only products succeed by looking personal, not institutional. The visual design for agent-recruited hosts should feel invited, not marketed-to.

typography: Inter 600 for names and property titles
Inter 400 for body text and descriptions
DM Sans 500 for agent name attribution
new_tokens_needed: --surface-personal: a warm off-white tint (rgb(252, 250, 255)) specifically for agent-mediated content cards to distinguish them from platform-generated content

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Agent names and guest names must use --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on light backgrounds for maximum readability. Verification badges must maintain 4.5:1 contrast ratio.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Faces and names are always Tier 1 (largest, darkest, first position). Property details are Tier 2. Platform mechanics are Tier 3 (smallest, lightest). No page should have platform branding as Tier 1.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Warm, not cold. Soft backgrounds, not stark white. Trustworthy, not corporate.' Agent-mediated pages should use warmer backgrounds (off-white with purple tint) rather than stark white to create a personal, letter-like quality.

elements.title: Verification Evidence Visual Language: Show, Don't Badge
elements.problem: Platform verification badges ('Verified' with a checkmark) are a visual shorthand that assumes trust in the verifying institution. Dimitri doesn't trust the institution yet. A green checkmark next to 'Credit Check: Passed' tells Dimitri nothing he can independently verify. The visual language must show evidence, not just results.
elements.solution: Replace abstract verification badges with evidence-forward visual treatments. (1) Show the verification tier (credit score range, not just 'passed'). (2) Use document thumbnails for personal verification (redacted driver's license preview). (3) Reference quotes from landlord references, styled as testimonials. (4) The visual treatment should resemble a professional background check report, not a marketplace trust badge.

evidence.quote: Their driver's license, because you never know.
evidence.insight: Dimitri wants to see the document, not a badge saying the document was checked. Visual design must show evidence, not abstractions.

evidence.quote: Solve a hard problem so important that they are willing to join.
evidence.insight: The visual representation of verification IS the hard problem solution. If it looks convincing, the host joins. If it looks like marketing, they don't.

typography: IBM Plex Mono 500 for data-backed values (credit score ranges, reference counts)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Verification status text must be readable without color alone (use icons + text labels). Document preview thumbnails must have visible borders to distinguish from surrounding content.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Evidence > Badge > Methodology. The host sees the evidence first (document thumbnail, reference quote), the badge second (Verified), the methodology third (how we verified, on expand).
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Mono for data/trust (prices, stats, badges). IBM Plex Mono signals precision and reliability.' Verification data should use monospace for credit scores, reference counts, and date stamps to signal factual precision.

elements.title: Timezone-Aware Status Card for Remote Hosts
elements.problem: A remote host checking their property status from a different timezone at 11 PM local time needs a visual design optimized for quick scanning under fatigue. Current dashboard patterns use equal visual weight for all status items. A remote host needs a single dominant visual element (status: OK or NOT OK) with supporting details available but not competing for attention.
elements.solution: Use a single-headline status card with color-coded background: (1) Green-tinted background = everything is fine, scan complete in 3 seconds. (2) Amber-tinted background = something needs attention, details below. (3) Red-tinted background = action required now. The headline should be the only thing the host reads when checking from their phone in bed in Paris. Details are collapsed by default.

evidence.quote: I will be in Europe, actually for work.
evidence.insight: Europe = 6-9 hour timezone shift. Host will check status at night, before bed. Visual design must work for fatigued, timezone-shifted scanning.

evidence.quote: The Engagement Effect describes the increase in engagement as the network grows.
evidence.insight: The status card IS the engagement loop for remote hosts. If it's too complex to scan, the host stops opening the app and engagement dies.

typography: IBM Plex Mono 500 at 14px for dates and amounts
new_tokens_needed: --status-ok-bg: a very subtle green-purple tint for 'all clear' status cards
--status-attention-bg: a warm amber tint for 'needs attention' cards

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Status headline must be readable in dark mode AND light mode (remote hosts may check at night with dark mode). Background color tints must be subtle enough to not alarm but distinct enough to differentiate status levels.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Single headline > evidence thumbnail (cleaning photo or payment confirmation) > detail list. The headline alone must convey the full status. Everything else is supplementary.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Confident, not flashy. The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.' Status cards must be devoid of decoration — no illustrations, no icons for the sake of icons. The headline IS the design.

elements.title: Urgency-Aware Timeline Visual for Deal Progression
elements.problem: Dimitri's 'within next week' deadline creates urgency that the platform must visually acknowledge. If the deal progression looks open-ended (no dates, no timeline, no countdown), it conflicts with the host's sense of urgency. Conversely, if it looks like a pressure tactic (countdown timers, red urgency badges), it triggers the 'third party' distrust.
elements.solution: Use a gentle timeline visual that shows deal progression with dates. (1) Horizontal or vertical progress line showing: agent call (completed) -> host review (current) -> guest confirmation (next) -> deal signed (end). (2) Dates on each step, including the host's stated deadline as a soft reference point. (3) No countdown timers or red urgency. Instead, use proximity language: 'Ariel is ready — review when you have a moment.' The urgency is in the specificity (real dates, real names), not in the visual treatment.

evidence.quote: Ideally I want to like take care of things within next week.
evidence.insight: The host has a deadline. The visual must acknowledge it without pressuring.

evidence.quote: If there aren't enough users on a social network and no one to interact with, everyone will leave.
evidence.insight: The timeline visual communicates that the other side (guests) is actively engaged. This counters the anti-network effect of a silent, empty platform.

typography: Inter 400 at 12px for dates and descriptions

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Completed vs. pending steps must be distinguishable by color AND shape (filled dot vs. outlined dot) for accessibility.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Current step is visually dominant (larger dot, bolder text, active color). Completed steps are visible but recessive. Upcoming steps are lightest. The host's eye should land on 'what's happening now' first.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' The timeline should look like a high-end project tracker, not a cheap progress bar. Generous spacing, refined typography, no animation gimmicks.
